issue.title: TSC/TSR: Design of estimator-predictor class interface (light-weight)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This should be a full specification document, including:

- class methods, should include at least "fit" and "predict"
- class variables (if applicable)
- hyper-parameter interface methods, e.g., getter/setters

body: From #1 discussion @ViktorKaz suggestion: API extension for save/load and data I/O (as in mlaut)
Uploaded code for initial discussion to ``bench`` branch.
Thanks! I'm not sure though how you are planning to do the orchestration itself? That part seems not to be covered by the code in the bench branch. Would you like to explain in the Jan 29 meeting?

issue.title: TSC/TSR: evaluation functionality and interface to losses/metrics

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
implementation of rudimentary evaluation functionality, should include:
- computation of methods' predictions on test set, after training on training set
- computation of common average and aggregate losses/scores for classification and regression
- interface to metrics/scoring functionality as in sklearn
- at first, preliminary design of the above

Note: *not* full-blown orchestration and experiment management

Conditional on https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2 since calls the estimator interface which needs to be consolidated first.

body:
I created a new branch called `orchestration`. The code mostly follows the MLaut design.

See [this file](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/orchestration/orchestrator_test.py) for an example of how it works. I am also copying it below for easy reference.

```python
from sktime.experiments.orchestrator import Orchestrator
from sktime.resampling.single_split import Single_Split
import sktime
from sktime.highlevel import Task, TSCStrategy
from sktime.datasets import load_gunpoint
from sktime.classifiers.ensemble import TimeSeriesForestClassifier
import pandas as pd

train = load_gunpoint(split='TRAIN')
test = load_gunpoint(split='TEST')
data = pd.concat([train,test], axis=0)
task = Task(case='TSC', data=data, dataset_name='gunpoint',target='label')

clf = TimeSeriesForestClassifier()
strategy = TSCStrategy(clf)

orchestrator = Orchestrator()
orchestrator.set_tasks([task])
orchestrator.set_strategies([strategy])
orchestrator.set_resampling(Single_Split())

orchestrator.run()
```

I also have a question about the design of the task object. Why does the task not store the data? I changed this in this implementation in order to simplify things. However, if there is a good reason for it I can think of an alternative solution for the orchestration.

A version of the orchestration framework is implemented in the `orchestration` branch.
It can handle both in memory data and loading the datasets from the HDD.
The results are written in the uae format using `from sktime.utils.results_writing.write_results_to_uea_format` but this can be easily changed if another format is deemed more appropriate.

If you want to perform the bake off you need to save all datasets in separate directories and split them in test and train folds. I was working off the format of the datasets saved here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1gWnOD7pRkHcDHDn8CSp9IH66DYychOxa

Please see below an example of how this can be done:
```python
from sktime.experiments.data import DataHolder
from sktime.classifiers.ensemble import TimeSeriesForestClassifier
from sktime.highlevel import Task, TSCStrategy

clf = TimeSeriesForestClassifier()
strategy = TSCStrategy(clf)

dl = DataLoader(dts_dir='path/to/root/directory/where/dts/are/saved', task_types='TSC')
results = orchestrator.fit(data=dl,
                            strategies=[strategy]) #you can provide an array of strategies here, not just one
```

The orchestrator iterates efficiently though the datasets by loading only one dataset in memory at any point in time.

The `results` object returned from the estimator can be used for evaluation and benchmarking.

For example:

```Python
from sktime.analyze_results import AnalyseResults
from sktime.analyze_results.scores import ScoreAccuracy

analyze = AnalyseResults(results)
losses, losses_df = analyze.prediction_errors(metric=ScoreAccuracy())

avg_and_std = analyze.average_and_std_error(losses)
#other tests and functions are also implemented check sktime.analyze_results
#for example
analyze.plot_boxcharts(losses)
analyze.ranks(losses)
analyze.t_test(losses)
analyze.sign_test(losses)
analyze.ranksum_test(losses)
analyze.t_test_with_bonferroni_correction(losses)
analyze.wilcoxon_test(losses)
analyze.friedman_test(losses)
analyze.nemenyi(losses)

#This is copy-paste from mlaut and not all of these are relevant in the time series context
```
Further development needed:
1. Need to make the framework more general. At the moment it can handle only two use cases - in-memory and from HDD and relies on a certain structure of the datasets. If it is violated, the code will break. For example if the test/train splits are not saved in the directory with the correct suffix or if the `sktime.utils.load_data.load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe` function returns only the X without the y for a particular dataset. Do we have datasets with no class labels?
2. The orchestrator should save the estimators. However, this should probably be implemented in the strategy class, not the orchestrator.
3. The experiments should resume from the last trained strategy in case of a crash.
4. Implement the option to recreate the `results` object from the saved results of the experiments.
5. Expand the available statistical tests in `analyze_results` to include metrics relevant for the time series context such as Diebold-Mariano test, etc. 
6. Optimise the code for computing clusters

Feel free to point out other areas of development as well as suggest priority of the tasks for future work

I wrote another implementation that handles the same use case in which the datasets are saved on disk and are pre-split. 

The difference is that:
1. the tasks are specified manually, and not created by the orchestrator
2. the paths to the datasets are individually specified.
3. the orchestrator design also potentially allows k-fold cross validation. Check the new orchestrator.run() method. However, we this is not fully implemented at the moment. We need to discuss how the predictions on the k splits need to be handled (calculate average, most votes, etc.)

From the user perspective this looks like this:

```python
from sktime.experiments.orchestrator import Orchestrator
from sktime.highlevel import Task, TSCStrategy
from sktime.classifiers.ensemble import TimeSeriesForestClassifier
from sktime.experiments.data import DatasetHDD
from sktime.model_selection import SKtime_PredefinedSingleSplit
from sktime.datasets import load_gunpoint
import pandas as pd


dts_ArrowHead = DatasetHDD(dataset_loc='data/datasets/ArrowHead', dataset_name='ArrowHead', target='target')
task_ArrowHead = Task(case='TSC', data=dts_ArrowHead, target='target')

dts_Beef = DatasetHDD(dataset_loc='data/datasets/Beef', dataset_name='Beef')
task_Beef = Task(case='TSC', data=dts_Beef, target='target')

clf = TimeSeriesForestClassifier()
strategy = TSCStrategy(clf)

orchestrator = Orchestrator()

predef_split = SKtime_PredefinedSingleSplit(dataset_loc='data/datasets', train_suffix='_TRAIN.ts', test_suffix='_TEST.ts')

orchestrator.run(tasks=[task_ArrowHead, task_Beef], datasets=[dts_ArrowHead, dts_Beef], strategies=[strategy], cv=predef_split)
```
